 I'm going to pick a bone with how anti-individual right advocate Saul Cornell has framed his opinion piece. Previously I have seen Cornell allowing his ideology to completely misconstrue U.S. v. Cruikshank, and he lost all credibility with me for doing so:

 However, it's not honest to simply ignore this latest message by blaming the motivations of the messenger. I would rather expose some history Cornell does not choose to recognize when he made his assertion: "If the Founders had imbibed the strong gun rights ideology that drives today's gun debate we would all be drinking tea and singing, 'God save our gracious Queen." From this he clearly implies the founders rejected the "gun right's ideology" of the existence of an individual RKBA. 
 
 Yet the reality is that the beginning of revolutionary war armed resistance was made possible because of the pre-existing individual RKBA. Cornell mentions the "Minutemen," but he does not describe them further in his opinion piece. To do so would force him to acknowledge that they agreed to appear within a minute bearing their privately held arms. They did not agree to meet at a central armory to have their arms handed out to them.
 
 True, his example is of an agreement involving some government direction and regulation of these men volunteering for militia service-but he chooses to avoid the fact that this militia organization was an offshoot of the already recognized right (and reality) of the people to keep and bear private arms. The volunteers already had and in many cases were exercising the individual RKBA. The right to have these arms did not suddenly come into being because of an agreement to become a militia member. They merely agreed to further exercise the RKBA by voluntarily submitting to militia organization. 
 
 And this "gun right's ideology" concept of an individual RKBA was not confined to Cornell's example of the "minutemen." There are a number of other examples, and evidence of both tolerance for and agreement with the concept of an armed public from which militia members may be called forth is easy to find if one looks. 
 
 George Mason has been mentioned, and he provides an excellent example of how the founders did not create a RKBA, they instead used the pre-existing RKBA as a vehicle to create militias. When Cornell comments on "gun rights ideology" and tea parties he does not tell you George Mason adopted, without official government assistance or direction, the "Fairfax Militia Plan":
 
 "Embodying the people. . . .a well regulated militia, composed of the Gentlemen, Freeholders, and Freedmen. . .[to protect] out Ancient Laws & Liberty. . . .[the volunteer members of which agreed to the following] And we do each of us, for ourselves respectively, promise and engage to keep a good Fire-lock in proper Order, & to furnish Ourselves as soon as possible with, & always keep by us, one Pound of Gunpowder, four Pounds of Lead, one Dozen Gunflints, & a pair of Bullet-Moulds, with a Cartouch Box, or powder horn, and Bag for Balls." I Mason, PAPERS, pp. 215-216 (1970).
 
 The RKBA was not suddenly created in Fairfax, Virginia by this agreement to maintain private firearms. It pre-existed the plan and was the right which made this plan of privately armed militia members feasible. 
 
 Mason was not the only founder to embrace (without governmental direction) the "gun right's ideology" of making use of the individual RKBA and a privately armed populace prepared to defend liberty. Cornell also ignores the creation of Patrick Henry's "Hanover Independent Militia Company," which caused Lord Dunmore, then royal governor of Virginia, to exclaim that its members:

 And, if Cornell had looked, he would have seen that the Governor later complained:
 
 "Every County is now Arming a Company of men whom they call an independent Company for the avowed purpose of protecting their Committee, and to be employed against Government if occasion require." J. Matthews, RICHARD HENRY LEE, p. 30 (1978)
 
 The "gun right's ideology" of an individual RKBA even found back-handed endorsement in a complaint made by the Continental Congress. It stemmed from an act in 1768 whereby the citizens of Boston called upon one another to arm themselves with privately held arms (as was their recognized pre-existing right):
 
 "Instances of the licentious and outrageous behavior of the military conservators of the peace still multiply upon us, some of which are of such a nature, and have been carried to so great lengths, as must serve fully to evince that a late vote of this town, calling upon the inhabitants to provide themselves with arms for their defense, was a measure as prudent as it was legal. . . .It is a natural right which the people have reserved to themselves, confirmed by the Bill of Rights, to keep arms for their defense; and as Mr. Blackstone observes, it is to be made use of when the sanctions of society and law are found insufficient to restrain the violence of oppression." O. Dickerson ed., Boston Under Military Rule, p79 (1936) [quoting from what was at the time the most widely circulated periodical in the colonies, A Journal of the Times].
 
 These weapons were later taken by trickery in the first known "registration and secured storage" scheme imposed in America-generating the following Continental Congress complaint:
 
 "The inhabitants of Boston being confined within that town by the general their governor, and having, in order to procure their dismission, entered into a treaty with him, it was stipulated that the said inhabitants having deposited their arms with their own magistrates, should have liberty to depart, taking with them their own effects. They accordingly delivered up their arms, but in open violation of honor, in defiance of the obligation of treaties, which even savage nations esteemed sacred, the governor ordered the arms deposited as aforesaid, that they might be preserved for their owners, to be seized by a body of soldiers; detained the greatest part of the inhabitants in the town, and compelled the few who were permitted to retire, to leave their most valuable effects behind." DECLARATION OF THE CAUSES AND NECESSITY OF TAKING UP ARMS (July 6, 1775).
 
 Now some of these examples involve governmental direction or organization and some do not-but every one of them shows the strength of the founder's "gun right's ideology" of condoning a broad pre-existing individual RKBA and making use of it when desired to create a militia organization. 
 
 There are many, many more examples of the founder's belief in the "gun right's ideology" of the individual RKBA. Here are just two more examples:
 
  "SIR,
 Your letter of Sep. 15. 1777 from Paris comes safe to hand. . . . From the kind anxiety expressed in your letter as well as from other sources of information we discover that our enemies have filled Europe with Thrasonic accounts of victories they had never won and conquests they were fated never to make. While these accounts alarmed our friends in Europe they afforded us diversion. We have long been out of all fear for the event of the war. I enclose you a list of the killed, wounded, and captives of the enemy from the commencement of hostilities at Lexington in April, 1775, until November, 1777, since which there has been no event of any consequence. This is the best history of the war which can be brought within the compass of a letter. I believe the account to be near the truth, tho' it is difficult to get at the numbers lost by an enemy with absolute precision. Many of the articles have been communicated to us from England as taken from the official returns made by their General. I wish it were in my power to send you as just an account of our loss. But this cannot be done without an application to the war office which being in another county is at this time out of my reach. I think that upon the whole it has been about one half the number lost by them, in some instances more, but in others less. This difference is ascribed to our superiority in taking aim when we fire; every soldier in our army having been intimate with his gun from his infancy."
 Thomas Jefferson. Letter to Giovanni Fabbroni, Williamsburg, June 8, 1778, The Letters of Thomas Jefferson, 1743-1826.
 
 "Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom of Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any bands of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive." Noah Webster, "An Examination into the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution" (1787) in Pamphlets on the Constitution of the United States (P. Ford, 1888).
 
 Jefferson and Webster are here extolling (and likely also exaggerating) the very individual RKBA "gun right's ideology" which Cornell implies these same men must have rejected. 
 
 I recognize that Cornell was making a point of the need for governmental regulation of a militia. I do not disagree with this position. I believe it was Socrates who said something to the effect of "a disorganized mob is no more an army than a heap of stone building materials is a house." Cornell would likely agree with me that there is truth in that statement regardless of who said it. But when Cornell seeks to limit the relevance of revolutionary history to governmental regulation of the militia he forgets the pre-existing right which provided the source of the building materials the founders used in that organization: 
 
 "And further, that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves and of a kind in common use at the time." United States v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174, 179 (1939) 
 
 The government absolutely has the authority to regulate the militia and the arms the militia uses. But Cornell's talk of tea parties and "God save the Queen" cannot hide his desire to have the militia "tail" wag the individual RKBA "dog."
